Trump says he will name Alice Johnson, whom he pardoned, as ‘pardon czar’ President Donald Trump said Alice Marie Johnson, a Black woman whom he pardoned in 2020, would be his “pardon czar,” saying he would listen to Johnson’s recommendations on pardons. Johnson, who was in the audience at the White House Black History Month reception, spent more than two decades in prison for a nonviolent drug offense. Trump commuted her life sentence in 2018, then pardoned her in 2020 after she spoke at the Republican National Convention. “You’ve been an inspiration to people, and we’re going to be listening to your recommendation on pardons,” Trump said Thursday, addressing Johnson as he spoke at the event. “You’re going to be — she’s going to be my pardon czar. And you’re going to find people just like you that should not, this should not have happened. … So you’re going to look and you’re going to make recommendations and I’ll follow those recommendations, okay? For pardons. All right?” After her release during Trump’s first term, Johnson came to have some role in the clemency process, The Washington Post reported in 2020. Trump granted clemency to three women who were in prison with Johnson, partially working on her recommendation. At the time, in public remarks, Trump suggested Johnson could give him other names of people to pardon.
